comment_text:
Some added notes (I may come back to add more later):

1) There's a slight error in the video where I say the answer is floor(pi/theta). Really it should be ceil(pi/theta) - 1, to account for the cases where pi/theta is an integer. For example, when the mass ratio is 1, theta will be pi/4, so pi/theta is 4, but there are 3 clacks. As stated in the video, though, you still think about this is "how many times can you add theta to itself before it surpasses (or equals) pi?"


2) What I animate here as I say "angle of reflection" and "angle of incidence" differs a little with convention. Typically in optics, you look at the angle between the beam and a line perpendicular to the mirror, rather than with the mirror itself.

3) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ≈ x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

4) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word “phase space” to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. This is common in the context of math, but you should know, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the “phase space” here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term “configuration space”, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we did here.

I hope you enjoyed this little sequence. I still get happy whenever I think about the phenomenon and the various explanations for it.

Wow!   Math is so cool.   I did it another way using symmetry.   Since the original problem simply involves the reflection/rotation of the total momentum vector, one can model the angled wall 'trick' by shooting some test mass into the two walls parallel to the bisector of the angle (and not parallel to one of the walls).   Now taking that angle (which is just theta/2) you can see that the total number of angle changes imparted by the walls before the test mass will no longer hit a wall and "escapes" is the total angle turned by the test mass  (summing up each reflection's change in angle using the basic law of reflection).  Consider the angle changes from the reference frame of the test mass. The integer part of number of angle changes encountered by the test mass corresponds to the number of bounces by the two masses. This works if you include the original turn made to make the path of the test mass parallel to the bisector which is required to ensure the same symmetry as the original two mass problem.

Hey OP, so I'm not a physicist or really bright at physics, but I have a question. We see that almost everything in our daily lives, and everything in Physics, Maths and Science in general, has Pi in it. And Pi is irrational. We have computed its value to trillions of digits, but we will obviously never compute (or physically witness) the actual value. Only ever approximations upto n digits.
My question: So what if we use Pi as our standard unit to measure. Our Unit. Make Pi the "One" of Math. Wouldn't that make computation (and in general, every math and every equation) so much simpler? Pi is no longer 3.14159265358979323 of 1. It's just 1.
It would be like multiplying all equations with 1/Pi, make calculations of "squares" difficult instead, but it would still simplify most equations with Pi in it. Which is a lot.

for the part where the connection is mentioned between the conservation laws and the angle of reflection: the same can be understood when we derive the law of reflection and the law of refraction (Snell’s law) using the interface conditions of electromagnetic fields (which can be derived from the Maxwell equations). with this approach we can relate the angular frequencies (and also the wave vectors) of the incident and reflected/refracted waves (in geometrical optical analogy: rays). combining these with the simple quantumphysical equations of energy & angular frequency and momentum vector & wave vector (these pairs are related by the Planck constant, separately), we can see that the laws of reflection and refraction come from the conservation of energy and momentum (because of the conservation of energy the frequency does not change between the mediums and because of the conservation of momentum the wave vector does change between the mediums). and if we go even deeper with Noether’s theorem we can see and understand how the abstract symmetries of the physical system (invariances) connect seemingly very different areas such as the conservation of physical quantites and the path of light rays or electromagnetic waves. and the really striking and interesting part of this for me is the fact that the Maxwell equations implicitly but inherently carries the conservation laws. i am sure that the true and deep understanding cannot be achieved without connecting the analogies.

Something was bothering me about these solutions. Basically, they all depend on m1 being a factor of 100 times m2, but why is 100 so magical? If we didn't use a base 10 system, would this have ever been found? The answer I finally came up with is yes. If you take the result (the number of clicks), then multiply it by sqrt(m2/m1)/(m2/m1), no matter what the ratio of m1 is to m2, you always get a number approaching pi. The bigger the ratio is, the more accurate the result is. This explains why 100 works so well - it will always be a factor of 10 higher. But it also explains why this would work in other base systems. For example, if m1 were 16,777,216 times the mass of m2 (or 0x100000), the resulting number of clicks is 12,867, or 0x3243. In hex, the first 4 digits of pi are  3.243!

Oh, how I miss the days when I had epiphanies such as these! At age 19, I worked out a formula which generalizes the volume of a sphere to higher dimensions.

S = 2^d*r^d * product(integral(sin(x)^n , x , 0 , 1) , n , 1 , d)

where S is the space occupied by the hypersphere, r is the radius, and d is the number of dimensions the hypersphere has.

It was only after finding Wolfram Alpha that I learned that someone else had done something similar. They even generalized it to non-integer dimensions!

S = 2*pi^(d/2)*r^d/(d*gamma(d/2)). Here, gamma(x) is a generalized form of the factorial (x-1)! to include non-integers.

And with THAT preamble out of the way, my question is this: why does the gamma function show up in product series even when the terms aren't sequential?

At 2:37 you say that this doesn’t quite work in optics because the two angles are not equal,and that is true,if the mass of those objects are not equal.
Let’s imagine that the red dot on the graph is an object which has mass: if the object is coming in from the right and the angle of incidence is 45,because of it’s mass,the object has inertia so the angle of reflection will be smaller.In the case of optics,the light particle has no mass,therefor no inertia,so the angle of reflection is equal to the angle of incidence.This way,we can conclude that the ratio between those two objects mass is directly proportional to the inertia of the object represented by the dot.

At 12:55, it's not quite the floor of pi/theta. Consider m1=m2=1, theta=pi/4. There are exactly three collisions (m1->m2, m2->wall, m2->m1), yet pi/(pi/4) is precisely 4. The broader description (max(n integer) s.t. theta*n < pi) is correct, it just doesn't define the floor function.

Just one question.Have you got a really neat way of showing that floor(pi/arctan(sqrt(massratio))) is always exactly the same as floor(pi/sqrt(massratio)); that is, that an off-by-one is impossible? In general this is false (there are many values of the mass ratio that do give an off-by-one), so we'd be after a proof that mass ratios equal to powers of 100 never give an off-by-one.

I've got as far as showing that this can only happen if the decimal expansion of pi includes a really, really long sequence of 9s (at least equal in length to the number of digits that precede it, subtract one), and I think we can assume that this is close to certain (in a probabilistic sense). But I haven't been able to prove it beyond all doubt.
Worth mentioning: The book "Introduction to Algorithm" described the FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) in a way that explains how FFT provides a different perspective for the same data.
